verses.text: I said in my heart, 'Come now, I will test you with pleasure; enjoy yourself.' But behold, this also was vanity.
verses.comment: The author tests pleasure as a solution for life's meaning but finds it empty. The pursuit of pleasure alone is ultimately unfulfilling, foreshadowing the gospel theme that only God satisfies (cf. John 4:13–14).

verses.text: I said of laughter, 'It is madness,' and of pleasure, 'What does it accomplish?'
verses.comment: Laughter and pleasure, when sought as ends in themselves, do not give true purpose. Compare with Luke 6:25, where Jesus warns about those who laugh now but will mourn, showing the deeper joy found in God.

verses.text: I searched with my heart how to cheer my body with wine—my heart still guiding me with wisdom—and how to lay hold on folly, till I might see what was good for the children of man to do under heaven during the few days of their life.
verses.comment: The speaker conducts deliberate testing of both pleasure and wisdom to discover meaning. The pursuit is a foreshadowing of man's search for fullness, ultimately pointing toward Christ who provides true life (John 10:10).

verses.text: I made great works; I built houses and planted vineyards for myself.
verses.comment: Material projects and achievements recall the tower of Babel (Gen. 11:4). The text highlights how human effort alone cannot provide ultimate security—a truth echoed in Matthew 6:19–21.

verses.text: I made myself gardens and parks, and planted in them all kinds of fruit trees.
verses.comment: Reference to gardens alludes to Eden (Gen. 2:8), reflecting the longing to recreate paradise by human means. Yet, true paradise is ultimately a gift from God (Rev. 22:1–2).

verses.text: I made myself pools from which to water a forest of growing trees.
verses.comment: Creating pools for sustaining life signals the human attempt to control and sustain creation, contrasting with God as the only true life-giver (cf. Jer. 2:13, John 7:37–38).

verses.text: I bought male and female slaves, and had slaves who were born in my house. I had also great possessions of herds and flocks, more than any who had been before me in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Owning servants and wealth mirrors the blessings given to patriarchs. Yet, the text emphasizes even such prosperity cannot secure lasting happiness outside of God, pointing towards spiritual riches (Luke 12:15–21).

verses.text: I also gathered for myself silver and gold and the treasure of kings and provinces. I got singers, both men and women, and many concubines, the delight of the sons of man.
verses.comment: Worldly riches, artistic pleasures, and sensual delights are amassed, yet these too are unable to fulfill the deep longing of the human heart. Compare 1 John 2:16—the desires of the flesh are fleeting.

verses.text: So I became great and surpassed all who were before me in Jerusalem; also my wisdom remained with me.
verses.comment: The speaker emphasizes his exceptional status and wisdom, yet finds that neither wisdom nor status apart from God fulfills the soul. Spiritual greatness depends on humility before God (Matthew 18:4).

verses.text: And whatever my eyes desired I did not keep from them; I kept my heart from no pleasure, for my heart found pleasure in all my toil, and this was my reward for all my labor.
verses.comment: The pursuit of pleasure and accomplishments is honestly acknowledged as enjoyable for a time. The transient satisfaction in human toil hints at the deeper joy meant to be found in God (Psalm 16:11).

verses.text: Then I considered all that my hands had done and the toil I had spent in doing it, and behold, all was vanity and a chasing after wind, and there was nothing to be gained under the sun.
verses.comment: After experiencing every form of satisfaction, the conclusion remains: only God can grant lasting meaning (Matt. 16:26). This verse sets the stage for understanding the futility of life apart from divine grace.

verses.text: So I turned to consider wisdom and madness and folly. For what can the man do who comes after the king? Only what has already been done.
verses.comment: The cyclical nature of man's effort underlines human limitation. Only revelation from God can break this cycle—a theme fulfilled in the New Covenant (2 Cor. 5:17).

verses.text: Then I saw that wisdom is better than folly, just as light is better than darkness.
verses.comment: Wisdom is affirmed as superior—a clear affirmation of the value of God's guidance (cf. John 8:12: Jesus as the Light of the world).

verses.text: The wise man has his eyes in his head, but the fool walks in darkness. Yet I perceived that the same event happens to them all.
verses.comment: Though wisdom brings light, both wise and foolish meet a common fate—death. This provokes longing for resurrection and greater hope, as fulfilled in Christ's victory over death (1 Cor. 15:22).

verses.text: Then I said in my heart, 'What happens to the fool will happen to me also. Why then have I been so very wise?' And I said in my heart that this also is vanity.
verses.comment: Worldly wisdom does not spare one from life's ultimate end. All human efforts apart from grace are ‘vanity;’ only God's wisdom endures through death (James 1:5, 1 Cor. 1:24).

verses.text: For of the wise, as of the fool, there is no lasting remembrance, seeing that in the days to come all will have been long forgotten. How the wise dies just like the fool!
verses.comment: Human fame and achievement are fleeting. The desire for lasting remembrance points to our need for eternal life in God (Luke 10:20).

verses.text: So I hated life, because what is done under the sun was grievous to me, for all is vanity and a chasing after wind.
verses.comment: The existential crisis described here can only find resolution in hope beyond the present age, fulfilled by union with God through Christ (Phil. 1:21, Rom. 8:18).

verses.text: I hated all my toil in which I toil under the sun, seeing that I must leave it to the man who will come after me,
verses.comment: Earthly accomplishments are transient. The desire that our works remain points toward the value of building on a spiritual foundation (1 Cor. 3:12–15).

verses.text: and who knows whether he will be wise or a fool? Yet he will be master of all for which I toiled and used my wisdom under the sun. This also is vanity.
verses.comment: Human legacies are unpredictable. This points toward the necessity of entrusting our labors to God’s providence and working for treasure that does not fade (Matt. 6:19–20).

verses.text: So I turned about and gave my heart up to despair over all the toil of my labors under the sun,
verses.comment: Despair emerges from the realization that one's efforts are ultimately out of human control. The remedy is found in surrendering to God’s will (Prov. 3:5–6).

verses.text: because sometimes a person who has toiled with wisdom and knowledge and skill must leave everything to be enjoyed by another who did not toil for it. This also is vanity and a great evil.
verses.comment: Inheritance can be an occasion for injustice or futility. This highlights the need for trust that justice is ultimately in God's hands—echoing Jesus’ teaching in Luke 12:13–21.

verses.text: What has a man from all the toil and striving of heart with which he toils beneath the sun?
verses.comment: This rhetorical question reinforces the theme of life's fleeting nature apart from God’s eternal plan. The recurrence invites reflection on life’s ultimate meaning (cf. Col. 3:23–24).

verses.text: For all his days are full of sorrow, and his work is a vexation. Even in the night his heart does not rest. This also is vanity.
verses.comment: Anxiety and restlessness show the limits of earthly effort. True rest is found only in God’s peace, communicated through His grace and presence (Matt. 11:28–30).

verses.text: There is nothing better for a person than that he should eat and drink and find enjoyment in his toil. This also, I saw, is from the hand of God,
verses.comment: Earthly blessings are to be received with gratitude as gifts of God, not idols. This joy reflects the sacramental vision of life as a gift, in which all is received from God and given back to Him (1 Tim. 4:4–5).

verses.text: for apart from Him, who can eat or who can have enjoyment?
verses.comment: Human enjoyment and true fulfillment depend on communion with God. This verse prefigures spiritual participation in God's life (John 6:53–57; Acts 17:28).

verses.text: For to the one who pleases Him, God gives wisdom and knowledge and joy, but to the sinner He gives the work of gathering and collecting, only to give to one who pleases God. This also is vanity and a chasing after wind.
verses.comment: God's grace is the true source of wisdom and joy. Even worldly gains serve God’s ultimate plan, distributing blessings according to His providence (Romans 8:28). Pleasing God is the key to fulfillment, suggesting the importance of responding to grace with obedience and faith.
